question_text:
A carpenter bought a piece of wood that was 6.5 metres long. Then she sawed 4.7 metres off the end. How long is the piece of wood now?


_ metres
solution:
Length of piece of wood now = Length of piece of wood bought - length of wood sawed.
So, Subtract the numbers of metres.
Remember to line up the decimal points.
The piece of wood is 1.8 metres long now.

question_text:
A mechanic bought a piece of chain that was 7.7 metres long. Then they used 5.7 metres off the end. How long is the piece of chain now?


_ metres
solution:
Length of piece of chain now = Length of piece of chain bought - length of chain used.
So, Subtract the numbers of metres.
Remember to line up the decimal points.
The piece of chain is 2.0 metres long now.

question_text:
A chef rolled out a piece of pasta dough that was 4.6 metres long. Then they cut 1.2 metres off the end. How long is the piece of pasta dough now?


_ metres
solution:
Length of piece of pasta dough now = Length of piece of pasta dough rolled out - length of pasta dough cut.
So, Subtract the numbers of metres.
Remember to line up the decimal points.
The piece of pasta dough is 3.4 metres long now.

question_text:

_ metres

So, Subtract the numbers of metres.
Remember to line up the decimal points.
The piece of measuring tape is 1.6 metres long now.
